title: 103_hr2328
content: The "Public Lands Corps Act of 1993" is cited as the short title for this Act. Congressional findings and purpose are outlined in the following sections. The Congress finds that utilizing young men and women in a Public Lands Corps can benefit them by providing education and work opportunities, enhancing their understanding of natural resources, and helping them pay for higher education. This also benefits the nation's economy and environment. The Public Lands Corps provides education and work opportunities for young individuals, helping them pay for higher education and benefitting the nation's economy and environment. Many facilities and natural resources on public lands and Indian reservations require labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration work. The Public Lands Corps aims to address the need for labor-intensive rehabilitation and restoration of facilities and natural resources on public lands and Indian reservations, which federal agencies cannot manage alone. Youth conservation corps have a proven track record of cost-effective and efficient maintenance in partnership with government land management agencies. The purpose of this Act is to perform conservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and improvement work on public lands and Indian lands in a cost-effective manner. Youth conservation corps have a good record of efficiently maintaining these facilities in partnership with government land management agencies. The Act aims to perform conservation, rehabilitation, restoration, and improvement work on public lands and Indian lands in a cost-effective manner. It also aims to expose young individuals to public service and expand educational opportunities. The Act aims to involve young individuals in public service and conservation careers by providing educational opportunities and exposure to natural and cultural resources on public lands. The Act aims to involve young individuals in public service and conservation careers by providing educational opportunities and exposure to natural and cultural resources on public lands. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Corps" as the Public Lands Corps, "public lands" as lands owned or administered by the United States, and "qualified youth or conservation corps" as programs offering full-time work for individuals aged 16 to 25. The term "qualified youth or conservation corps" refers to programs that offer full-time work for individuals aged 16 to 25 in natural or cultural resource settings, providing a mix of work experience, skills, education, training, and support services. The term "qualified youth or conservation corps" offers full-time work for individuals aged 16 to 25 in natural or cultural resource settings, providing a mix of work experience, skills, education, training, and support services, as well as the opportunity to develop citizenship values and skills through service to their community and the United States. The term "Indian tribe" includes any group recognized as an Indian tribe by the Secretary of the Interior. The term "Indian tribe" means any Indian tribe, band, nation, or group recognized as such by the Secretary of the Interior, including Native village corporations and groups established under the Alaska Native Claims Settlement Act. The term "Indian" refers to a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" encompass any real property owned by them. The term "Indian" means a person who is a member of an Indian tribe, and "Indian lands" include real property owned by Indian tribes, held in trust by the United States, or subject to restrictions on alienation. The term "State" refers to any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, or the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, Virgin Islands, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The term "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" refers to projects for preserving natural, cultural, and historic resources. The term "conservation, restoration, or rehabilitation project" includes projects for preserving natural, cultural, historic, archaeological, recreational, or scenic resources in various states and territories. SEC. 4. PUBLIC LANDS CORPS PROGRAM. Establishment of Public Lands Corps in the Department of the Interior and Agriculture for young men and women aged 16-25 enrolled by the Secretaries. Participants must be citizens or residents of the US, possess a high school diploma or equivalent, or agree to obtain one. Persons enrolled in the Corps must be citizens or permanent residents of the US, possess a high school diploma or agree to obtain one, and not have dropped out of school to join the program. Enrollment is not subject to US civil service laws. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can also establish Qualified Youth or Conservation Corps. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can enroll individuals in the Corps without regard to civil service laws. They can also contract with qualified youth or conservation corps to carry out projects on public lands. The Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture can utilize the Public Lands Corps or qualified youth/conservation corps for conservation projects on public or Indian lands, with a preference for projects providing long-term public benefits. Preference for projects under this Act includes long-term public benefits, instilling work ethic, being labor-intensive, prompt initiation, and providing educational opportunities. Projects under this Act must provide long-term public benefits, instill a work ethic and sense of public service, be labor-intensive, able to start promptly, and offer educational opportunities. All projects must align with relevant laws, policies, and management plans for public or Indian lands. The Act requires projects to offer educational opportunities and be consistent with relevant laws and management plans for public or Indian lands. Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture can provide necessary services and facilities for conservation centers. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture are authorized to provide services and facilities for conservation centers, including quarters, board, medical care, transportation, and logistical support from military installations. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture may establish and use conservation centers with logistical support from military installations for programs. Basic standards of health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety must be enforced at these centers. The Secretaries of Interior and Agriculture may establish conservation centers with support from military installations. They will provide temporary tent shelters, transportation, and supervision, ensuring health, nutrition, sanitation, and safety standards are met and enforced. Contracts with State, local government agencies, and private organizations may be made for center management. SEC. 5. RESOURCE ASSISTANTS. Authorization for the placement of qualified college students or recent graduates in Federal land managing agencies to carry out research or technical functions without regard to civil service laws. Participants will be recruited from colleges and universities. The Resource Assistant Program allows qualified college students or recent graduates to work in Federal land managing agencies without following civil service laws. Participants are recruited from colleges and universities, with a focus on diversity. The program aims to augment the workforce of Federal land managing agencies. The Resource Assistant Program aims to increase diversity by recruiting college students and recent graduates from various backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. The program's dual purposes are to enhance participants' exposure to the conservation agency workplace and augment the agencies' workforce. The Resource Assistant Program aims to increase diversity by recruiting college students and recent graduates from various backgrounds to work in Federal land managing agencies. Existing nonprofit organizations may also implement the program, and participating organizations are required to contribute to expenses. Nonprofit organizations can implement the Resource Assistant Program if they meet agency standards. Participating organizations must fund 25% of the total costs for each intern recruited through them. Nonprofit organizations supporting interns through private funding at 25% of total costs in the Resource Assistant program must submit an annual report evaluating the program's impact on the agency's mission. SEC. 6. LIVING ALLOWANCES AND TERMS OF SERVICE FOR PARTICIPANTS. Living allowances and terms of service for participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are provided by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture. Participants receive a living allowance not exceeding the maximum established for national service program participants. Each participant agrees to a term of service determined by the Secretaries. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program agree to a term of service set by the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture, similar to the national service program. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program may receive educational benefits or awards. Participants in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program are eligible for national service awards under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 if they meet the requirements set by the Secretaries of the Interior or Agriculture. The specifics of these awards, including their duration, purpose, and amount, will be determined according to the Act. The Act establishes requirements for eligibility for benefits and awards under the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program. The specifics of these benefits, including duration, purpose, and amount, will be determined as provided under the Act. Borrowers in the program may request forbearance on Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Borrowers in the Public Lands Corps and Resource Assistant program can request forbearance on Stafford Loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Lenders must grant forbearance to participants upon written request, in line with regulations set by the Secretary of Education. SEC. 8. Nondisplacement requirements apply to all activities of the Public Lands Corps and qualified youth or conservation corps under this Act. SEC. 9. Funding details. Cost Sharing: The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can pay up to 75% of project costs on public lands by qualified youth or conservation corps. The remaining 25% can come from nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is required for projects on Indian lands. The Public Lands Corps can receive up to 75% of project costs from federal agencies, with the remaining 25% covered by nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is needed for projects on Indian lands. Additionally, a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency may contribute to project costs for the Public Lands Corps. The Public Lands Corps can receive up to 75% of project costs from federal agencies, with the remaining 25% covered by nonfederal sources. No cost sharing is needed for projects on Indian lands. Additionally, a foundation associated with a Federal land managing agency may contribute to project costs for the Public Lands Corps. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture are eligible to receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act of 1990. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture can receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 without any cost sharing requirements. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretaries of the Interior and Agriculture to receive funds for programs under the National and Community Service Act of 1990 without cost sharing requirements.
